subject: RE: Mocking libraries and moving parts (was: Re: [junit] unit tes t    case for login())
msgSnippet: In one example I tried was a fairly simple piece of business logic. I needed to write some tests around a user belonging to a group. I needed at a minimum an
messageBody:
In one example I tried was a fairly simple piece of business logic. I needed
to write some tests around a user belonging to a group.

I needed at a minimum an implementation of IDfUser and IDfGroup. Due to the
nature of the beast it is most common to get these from the session
(IDfSession). As all of these are interfaces it wasn't too bad but each of
the interfaces extends others and have several hundred methods each. I
eventually decided that what I was trying to test in this case was
Documentum logic and that I should just trust the framework.

Another example is Documentum web components which are similiar in some ways
to JSF. These extend standard Documentum classes which provide a large
amount of functionality much of which eventually ties back to a functionaing
sql database via a custom interface and/or query language. In these cases
the best I could do was to test extracted business logic piecemeal.

Michael Rutherfurd



-----Original Message-----
From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
David Saff
Sent: Wednesday, 21 June 2006 12:05 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Mocking libraries and moving parts (was: Re: [junit] unit test case
for login())



Rutherford, Michael wrote:
> I've looked in passing at the various mocking libraries
> and they looked interesting but again required too many "moving parts" to
be
> useful for more than trivial tests.

Can you elaborate on this? I've used mocking libraries on some rather
non-trivial tests, but I'm willing to believe there are special features
in Documentum's API that make it hard. I'm curious what those features
are. Thanks,

David Saff
